awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2021: Linking soil microbiome to pulsed trace gas emissions in rewetted drylands
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2021, Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supports research and training of the Fellow that will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways. A major pathway of carbon and nitrogen loss from soils is via gaseous emission to the atmosphere that occurs as a result of microbial metabolism in the soil; many are notorious greenhouse gases (e.g., carbon dioxide and nitrous oxide) and gases that affect air quality (e.g., volatile organic compounds and nitric oxide). However, it is still unclear what regulates gaseous emissions from soils: are they the result of specific traits and activities of organisms in the soil or are they the result of the environment in which the organisms are living? In hot, dry ecosystems, soil emissions are generally low, but “pulses” of large emissions usually occur after rain or irrigation events when soils are wet enough for plant and microbial metabolism to thrive. This gas pulse phenomenon provides a unique opportunity to link simultaneous changes in soil biology, movement of nutrients in the soil, and the gaseous (by)products of metabolism that are released. The research project will use a combination of experimental approaches to connect soil processes to gaseous emissions in an agricultural context, where results can be used to engineer healthier farming systems and impact climate and air quality at a large scale; this will benefit workforce development partnerships and students from diverse backgrounds participating in the project. 

Research activities integrate molecular and isotopic tools with biogeochemical assays to quantify microbial and nutrient responses to rewetting of dry soils and relate these responses to trace gas pulses. Two experiments will be conducted in an agricultural study system to compare different aspects of soil conditioning that are known to affect trace gas pulses and presumably extend to microbe-environment interactions: (1) incremental nitrogen addition, and (2) crop genotype. Training activities include building skillsets in genomic, molecular, and isotopic tools and analyses, all of which are new frontiers of soil ecology and have rarely been used in combination to explain processes associated with nutrient cycling; mentoring graduate and undergraduate students with interest in interdisciplinary questions and approaches; and communicating the importance of soil health to the public and to policymaking and agricultural entities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Holly Andrews has completed a NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology in the conceptual area Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supported research and training of the fellow in new theoretical and analytical skillsets relating to nutrient cycling in drought-prone soils. A major pathway of carbon and nitrogen loss from soils is via gaseous emission to the atmosphere that occurs as a result of microbial metabolism in the soil; many are notorious greenhouse gases (e.g. carbon dioxide, nitrous oxide) and gases that affect air quality (e.g. volatile organic compounds, nitric oxide). However, it is still unclear what regulates gaseous emissions from soils: are they the result of specific traits and activities of soil organisms or are they the result of the nutrient environment in which the organisms are living? In hot, dry ecosystems, soil emissions are generally low, but “pulses” of large emissions usually occur after rain or irrigation events when soils are wet enough for plant and microbial metabolism to thrive. This gas pulse phenomenon provides a unique opportunity to link simultaneous changes in soil biology, movement of nutrients in the soil, and the gaseous (by)products of metabolism that are released.

Intellectual merit outcomes

During the lifetime of the award, the Fellow developed skills in analyzing and integrating datasets that include soil trace gas concentrations, gene expression and taxonomic composition (metagenomes and metatranscriptomes) of soil microbial communities, and plant and soil biochemistry (metabolomes). These skills, at the cutting edge of soil ecology and biogeochemistry, were applied to two research projects which will result in at least four authored (two primary, two co-authored) publications for the fellow. In a tropical forest context (Biosphere 2, Oracle, AZ, USA), she observed that the presence of plant rhizospheres – regions of soil that surround and are in direct contact with plant roots – provided a buffer against extreme drought for soil microbes involved in nitrogen metabolism and production and consumption of nitrous oxide. Rhizospheres were also able to maintain more complete pathways of nitrogen (re)cycling compared to bulk soils throughout drought and recovery, indicating the importance of plants for maintaining and controlling microbial activities during extreme weather events. In tropical forests where droughts are becoming more frequent, rhizospheres of large plants may be key to mitigating losses of nitrogen greenhouse gases from soils to the atmosphere.

In an agricultural context (Maricopa Agricultural Center, Maricopa, AZ, USA) the Fellow traced nitrogenous emissions from sorghum agricultural soils to competitive interactions between plant roots and soil microbes for different forms of inorganic nitrogen fertilizer. Across multiple sorghum genotypes, she quantified the influence of plant traits on fertilizer use efficiency and potential reductions in field greenhouse gas emissions. Within sorghum rhizospheres, the Fellow observed differential fates for aqueous ammonium and nitrate fertilizer additions. Ammonium was preferentially acquired for immediate synthesis into organic forms, such as DNA and soil and plant organic matter, while nitrate was preferentially shunted into storage within root vacuoles or lost from soils as nitric and nitrous oxide. More productive sorghum genotypes showed increased metabolic activity in their rhizospheres, leading to higher soil nitrous oxide concentrations compared to low productivity rhizospheres. For sorghum cropping systems, these findings suggested that ammonium-based fertilizers may have dual and immediate benefits: mitigating direct N losses as greenhouse gases and promoting the rapid development of nitrogen-rich organic matter in agricultural soils.

Broader impacts outcomes

Expanding into the field of “omics” and bioinformatics increased and diversified leadership and networking opportunities for the Fellow, including her first invitation to speak at a departmental seminar and to serve on an external grant review panel. The Fellow co-organized events at one state and one national conference that supported professional development of early career researchers, and she presented results from Fellowship research at four conferences spanning state to international scales. Andrews collaborated heavily with research scientists across academic (University of Arizona), government (US Department of Energy National Laboratories), and industry (Aerodyne Research, Inc.) sectors, where she developed an understanding of overlaps and divergences in research priorities and operations across public and private entities that helped to refine her career goals. These experiences resulted in continuing partnerships and opportunities for future funding in nitrogen cycling research through multiple technological lenses.

Within the University of Arizona, she mentored three undergraduate students in rhizosphere biogeochemistry research projects, where she supported mentee development of analytical skills in soil and plant biochemistry data as well as conceptual understanding of rhizosphere nitrogen (and carbon) metabolism. The Fellow served as a guest lecturer in two ecosystem ecology courses focusing on topics of global nitrogen cycling and soil biogeochemistry, and she organized and moderated a career development event for postdoctoral researchers on campus.
